title: User query: Plan description from client LLM
log: Make a Wayang Plan that take the cities in relevant municipalities textfile and returns all organisations which have a matching municipality in the textfile. The textfile only have cities so you need to check if the city is in the municipality column. Output the result in a textfile.

title: Agent: SpecifierAgent Output
log:
Create an Apache Wayang plan that does the following:

- Input: a text file ("relevant municipalities") that contains a list of city names (one city per line).
- Input: a dataset of organisations that includes a column/field named "municipality" (each organisation record has a municipality string).
- Operation: for each organisation, check whether the organisation's municipality contains (or matches) any city from the "relevant municipalities" text file. Treat the municipality field as a string that may include the city; return organisations where the municipality contains a city from the text file.
- Output: write all matching organisation records to a text file (one organisation record per line, or serialized in a reasonable text representation).

Notes:
- Do not modify the input files.
- The plan should read the cities file, read the organisations dataset, perform the matching by checking if the city string appears in the organisation's municipality field, and write the matched organisations to an output text file.

log.thoughts: The plan needs the organisation table to match organisations.organisation_id and organisation.municipality. It also requires the text file that contains the list of cities (the user-described 'cities in relevant municipalities' textfile) so we can check whether each city appears within organisation.municipality. If the exact filename is uncertain, I included a reasonable filename for that text file so the Plan Builder can locate or confirm it.

steps.detailed_description: Read the text file named "relevant municipalities" as a line-oriented input (each line is one city name). Also read the JDBC table organisation with all columns (organisation_id, organisation_no, active_organisation, name, social_housing_org, municipality). Output: two datasets: cities (one city string per record) and organisations (full organisation records).

Filter the organisations dataset by checking, for each organisation record, whether its municipality string (organisation.municipality) contains any city string from the cities dataset. Input: organisations and cities. Output: the subset of organisation records where organisation.municipality contains (substring match) a city from the cities dataset. This step represents the matching/semi-join logic (broadcast or join + filter) rather than modifying inputs.

Write all matching organisation records (one record per output line, using a reasonable text serialization such as CSV or JSON per line) to the requested output text file. Do not modify the input files.

log.thoughts: Load the two inputs, perform a binary matching step to keep organisations whose municipality string contains any city from the cities file, and then write the matched organisations out. Three steps keep the plan concise and align with the requested flow.

title: Class: StepHandler created step dependencies and queue

log.thoughts: Read municipalities file (trim lines) as cities dataset (op 2). Read organisation JDBC table as organisations dataset (op 3).

operations.udf: (t: (String, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record)) => { val city = t._1.toString; val muni = Option(t._2.getField(5)).map(_.toString).getOrElse(""); muni.contains(city) }

log.thoughts: Read cities from text file and trim; read organisations via JDBC; perform cartesian join by constant key then filter pairs where organisation.municipality contains the city; output the organisation Records.

operations.table: (SELECT organisation_id, organisation_no, active_organisation, name, social_housing_org, municipality FROM organisation) as X

operations.udf: (t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val city = t._1._2.toString.toLowerCase; val rec = t._2._2; val muni = if (rec.getField(5) != null) rec.getField(5).toString.toLowerCase else ""; muni.contains(city) }

log.thoughts: Load cities and organisations, create a cross-product by key=1, filter by substring match of municipality contains city, serialize matching organisation records to lines and write to output.

title: Class: StepHandler merged subplans to full plan

operations.table: (SELECT organisation_id, organisation_no, active_organisation, name, social_housing_org, municipality FROM organisation) as X

operations.udf: (t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val city = t._1._2.toString.toLowerCase; val rec = t._2._2; val muni = if (rec.getField(5) != null) rec.getField(5).toString.toLowerCase else ""; muni.contains(city) }
(line: String) => line.toString.trim match { case s if s.nonEmpty => Seq(s) case _ => Seq.empty[String] }

operations.table: (SELECT organisation_id, organisation_no, active_organisation, name, social_housing_org, municipality FROM organisation) as X

operations.udf: (t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val city = Option(t._1._2).getOrElse("").toString.toLowerCase; val rec = t._2._2; val muni = Option(rec.getField(5)).map(_.toString.toLowerCase).getOrElse(""); muni.contains(city) }

(t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val r = t._2._2; val f = (i: Int) => Option(r.getField(i)).map(_.toString).getOrElse(""); s"${f(0)},${f(1)},${f(2)},${f(3)},${f(4)},${f(5)}" }

log.thoughts: Refined UDFs to trim and lowercase city names and municipality strings, used a constant join key to broadcast cities to organisations, added null-safety when reading record fields, and serialized matched organisation records as CSV lines for output.

title: Class: PlanMapper Mapped the refined plan finalized for execution

data.udf: (line: String) => line.toString.trim match { case s if s.nonEmpty => Seq(s) case _ => Seq.empty[String] }

data.table: (SELECT organisation_id, organisation_no, active_organisation, name, social_housing_org, municipality FROM (SELECT organisation_id, organisation_no, active_organisation, name, social_housing_org, municipality FROM organisation) as X) as X

data.udf: (t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val city = Option(t._1._2).getOrElse("").toString.toLowerCase; val rec = t._2._2; val muni = Option(rec.getField(5)).map(_.toString.toLowerCase).getOrElse(""); muni.contains(city) }

(t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val r = t._2._2; val f = (i: Int) => Option(r.getField(i)).map(_.toString).getOrElse(""); s"${f(0)},${f(1)},${f(2)},${f(3)},${f(4)},${f(5)}" }

log.thoughts: Renamed the text file input name to 'relevant_municipalities' (no space). This fixes common filename validation issues where spaces in the 'inputFileName' lead to plan validation/execution errors. No other changes were made.

title: Agent Usage: RefinerAgent. Refines version 2 information

operations.table: (SELECT organisation_id, organisation_no, active_organisation, name, social_housing_org, municipality FROM organisation) as X

operations.udf: (t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val city = Option(t._1._2).map(_.toString.toLowerCase).getOrElse(""); val rec = t._2._2; val muni = Option(rec.getField(5)).map(_.toString.toLowerCase).getOrElse(""); city.nonEmpty && muni.contains(city) }

(t: ((Int, String), (Int, org.apache.wayang.basic.data.Record))) => { val r = t._2._2; val f = (i: Int) => Option(r.getField(i)).map(_.toString).getOrElse(""); s"${f(0)},${f(1)},${f(2)},${f(3)},${f(4)},${f(5)}" }

plan.thoughts: Kept the original join-based approach (broadcasting cities via a constant key) and hardened UDFs against nulls; renamed the text file inputs/outputs to safe filenames and ensured string lowercasing before contains-check for case-insensitive matching.
